reviewText: I loved this animation, even though the creator (the awesome R. Crumb) hated it so much he killed the character off!  And, unlike "Wizards", I don't feel guilty liking it.Ah, Fritz, so much a lot of young, single guys see in themselves when they see it.  Fritz was mainly out to get laid, and 'went with the flow' to be smooth with the ladies.  However, he also got actually into the real issues and concerns of the sixties, along with the dark underside.Sexy, funny, dark, violent and ugly, it is truly a classic!

reviewerName: Bryan Byrd "reviewer of bad films and good books"
reviewText: When considering 'Fritz the Cat', I will say that it is an equal opportunity offender - nearly any group of people can find find something here to feel insulted by.  That doesn't necessarily make this a throw-away film though.  An insult may or may not contain elements of the truth, but in 'Fritz's' case, I think one can be reasonably assured that it contained the perspective of the filmmakers during the final days of the 1960's.  That Robert Crumb, the creator of 'Fritz the Cat' hated Bakshi's film is neither here nor there - Crumb's work contains far more puerile and offensively insulting material than Bakshi's does.But the purpose of this review is not to comment on that feud - I'm only concerned with the movie itself.  There seems to be two predominant opinions about this movie - One, that it is a tasteless, rascist, waste of time with juvenile depictions of cartoon animals having sex (which it is), or Two, a drug filled romp and laugh fest about a cool cat who lives every day like it's his last (which it also is, sort of).  Both these extremes miss the point I took away from the film, which was the commentary on a period of time in America that was coming down from its self-induced drug highs and battling with the realities that the Pie-in-the-sky social revolution couldn't face.There is power in animation - an animated character can do and say things that a live person would be excoriated for.  For instance, when Fritz decides to hang out in Harlem, to soak up the African-American 'experience', Bakshi exposes Fritz's utter ignorance about their lives.  Priveliged Fritz mouths liberal platitudes while trying to insinuate himself in the graces of a character named Duke, who sees right through him but by a quirk of fate decides to take the cat under his wing anyway (literally - all African Americans are represented as crows in the film).  Bakshi focuses his satire on the naive Fritz - the cat is a tourist in a land he knows nothing about, and doesn't care to know anymore than the false impressions he's already acquired.  Thus, hanging out in Harlem, for Fritz, is nothing more than a literal and metaphorical joy ride.This is the essence of Fritz.  He bounces from one situation to another, convinced of his perceptiveness and eager for the next life experience.  Except his perceptiveness is non-existant, and he careens down a path that leads to some very destructive stuff.  The final chapters of 'Fritz' are chilling, one example of where the 'free society' that people dreamed of in the late 60's could end.And through it all, Fritz never learns a thing.  Take this movie as you will, as a heap of garbage or as a hilarious romp.  The DVD release would certainly benefit from a commentary by Bakshi (Check out the "Wizards" DVD for a commentary where he drops a few tidbits about 'Fritz'), but taken on its own, I thought it was a pointed statement about the foolishness and inherent potential danger of the social movements of the late 60's.  NOT FOR CHILDREN.

reviewText: A crudely animated , poorly produced animated feature of tasteless humor , raunchy situations , and drugged out mania just happens to be my favorite animated film ever. Fritz is a two faced college dropout who wants to "bug out" and live each day as if it was his last , and pretty much every day in his life is almost his last as he burns his school , steals a car and goes on a crazy spin through the streets of Harlem wrecking anything in his path , insights a black riot , and finally blows up a power plant landing him in the hospital ..only to be awakened for a orgy on his hospital bed. Even though this film still carries an X rating it is very very tame by today's standards , not to mention very outdated. The animation is somewhat poor but it adds to the grittyness of the NY setting ..however the psychadelic color use in the background gets very very annoying..and it also contains some long scenes that would be better off cut (the Crowe dancing to Bo Didly , and the Rabbi's reading in the synagogue) but this film remains a cult classic nonetheless and should at least be viewed by anyone with an open mind or with a fondness for adult animation.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Let's get one thing straight: Fritz is a jerk. He's annoying and morally reprehensible in every way. (He finally gets a clue just before blowing himself up as a tool for a group of pseudo-revolutionaries). I remember sharing my feelings with a friend of mine, how I loved the movie, but how I hated Fritz."Are you trying to impose some kind of set of morals on Fritz the Cat, man?" was his reply.Oh yeah. Back to Earth. It's a cartoon, so sit back, relax, and enjoy watching the college-boy nitwit follow his, er, passions around with his head in the clouds, getting himself and everyone else around him into real world, lethal trouble. Perfect reflection of American society at the time the film was made; half the population with their heads up their asses while the other half got their heads and asses blown off, at home and abroad.One thing I'll say about Bakshi, for all his zaniness, he takes violence seriously. There is a great deal of violence in his films, but, as funny as his films are, the violent scenes are almost never funny in the least. Violence in a Bakshi film is horrific, gruesome, sickening, and serious as a heart attack.This film features some wonderfully stabbing satirical statements made about America's cultural dirty linens, delivered in the way that only Ralph Bakshi can.I'm a big fan of Bakshi and I highly reccomend this one, along with "Hey Good-Lookin" and "Street Fight," which is unquestionably my favorite.The sequels to Fritz the Cat were substandard crap, don't bother with them.You don't have to be high to enjoy Fritz the Cat...but it doesn't hurt.I've been waiting a loooong time for this to come out on DVD.Open up, you freebirds.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Fritz the Cat" looks much less revolutionary now than it did in the 1970s when it came out. The animation is flat, the characters are crude stereotypes in at least two instances that show how attitudes and perceptions change in forty years. (Police portrayed as unintelligent pigs and African Americans portrayed as over-sexed if cool drug pushers, pimps, whores drawn as crows... I am not joking!) Time to move on.
summary: A bit long in the tooth...

reviewerName: Eddie Landsberg "My 10th year as a reviewer !...
reviewText: Although Fritz's creator Robert Crumb supposedly wasn't so crazy about this film, I gotta say this is definitely the masterpiece its rumored to be... What's so wild about it (besides the incredibly funky Hammond organ laden Jazz soundtrack featuring the likes of Charles Earland and Merle Saunders) is that although it was made on the '70s and was a saracastic and twisted take on the '60s  the film is anything but dated, even with all the student revolutionary, free love and pot smoking in it... In fact,  I think its gotten even funnier with time... and if you're old enough to remember some of the "types" in this film... its even more funnier (or perhaps scarier.)...  What freaked me out was when I realized that even BLUE the meth addict neo-nazi motorcycle gang biker and his *literally* fat cow girlfriend reminded me of some real people  - - Though there aren't a lot of extra features, the trailer for the film is pretty wild and cool itself...Overall, Fritz the Cat, being one of those films who's scenes you watch over and over and over again is DEFINITELY worth getting... especially on DVD...  The kicks never wear off...
summary: He fought many a good man....

reviewText: "Fritz the Cat", the very first X-rated animated feature, is a good, yet strange film that is not for everybody. There are reasons to watch it and to avoid it. I personally like it.The film is about the adventures of a young hip cat (literally a cat) through 1960's New York. It follows him from his pot-fueled bathtub orgy to his brief association with a group of sadistic revolutionaries.The film has many positive attributes. It is a hilarious, yet pitch-black, satire of the 1960s and all of its pretensions and social standards (though was film was made in the early 70s, but it's close enough). The first part of the movie satirizes the generation gap and free love (that's where the orgy comes in). Later, the film tackles the racial tensions of the era when fritz goes to harlem and basically starts the biggest riot east of the Mississippi. This leads to a funny cameo by a few famous cartoon characters from Bakshi's biggest animation competitor. The film has a gritty, urban atmosphere to it, contributed in no small part by Bakshi's use of actual street dialogue. There is a scene in the crow bar (blacks are represented as crows in this movie) where a couple of crows are discussing black revolution. That was actual dialogue recorded by Bakshi. The atmosphere is also benefited by the animation. While sloppy in parts, much of the film has plenty of great personality animation. The animation was done by some of the best animators of the Golden Age like former Disney/Warners animators like Dick Lundy and Rod Scribner. The best bit is a piece done by Jim Tyer, formerly of Terrytoons (Mighty Mouse, Heckle and Jeckle). It is the part where Fritz chases and ravages Big Bertha while doped up. Fritz burns with animal lust in Jim Tyer's hands. It's not Disney, but it's not meant to be. Lastly, the great soundtrack completes the urban ambiance. It has a plethora of great artists, such as Billie Holliday.Although there are many positive aspects, the movie also has a few downfalls. Many of the characters, while interesting initially, kind of fall flat after awhile. Fritz is a very unlikeable character in many respects. He likes to think of himself as a great philosopher in the Kerouac-Beat tradition, but he's a total poseur out to get laid. While these contrasts could make interesting character development, the story does not really correlate the two personas well. The storytelling is also a weak point. i don't know if this comes from the original comic by R. Crumb (who wasn't that great at storytelling himself), but often a character is left behind but comes back later with no explanations. This is not helped by Bakshi's use of surreal imagery that doesn't add to anything. A few instances click (like the correlation of Duke the crow's death and the game of pool), but most fall flat. Another weak point is sometimes the image on the screen don't match the music. This is true of the scene where the violent revolutionaries are about to rape a horse girl. There's a buildup in the music, but the images just stick with a group shot without any resolution. We know what happens, but there's no emotional release. Speaking of rape, there is an excess amount of violence. That might turn some people off.Overall, it's good film that will undoubtedly leave an impression on everybody, whether you love it or hate it.
summary: Great Film Hasn't Lost Potency After Nearly Forty Years

reviewText: Fritz the Cat is based on a character created by underground comic book artist Robert Crumb and is written and directed by Ralph Bakshi. When it was released in 1972, it generated controversy for being the first X-rated cartoon. Crumb disowned the film upon its release and having seen it, it's understandable why.Skip Hinnant gives some charming voice work as Fritz the Cat, a New York University student. Beginning in the 1960s, we meet Fritz while he eavesdrops on a few female cats talking about racial issues with a black crow. Soon, Fritz lures the girls to a nearby party and has a marijuana-fueled orgy in the bathtub. His orgy is soon interrupted by the cops (personified by pigs) and Fritz, now a fugitive, runs to a nearby synagogue.The film has racial, religious, cultural, and social stereotypes throughout. The cops are, obviously, stereotypes, but are the funniest thing about the movie. It's a social commentary that is certainly a good example of the radical/drug culture of the 1960s, but if it's a comedy you're looking for...Look elsewhere. It's humorous and amusing, but never laugh-out-loud funny.The cheap-looking 70s animation is unique and fascinating, while obviously nowhere near as impressive as animated movies of today.The biggest problem I had with "Fritz the Cat" was how tedious it can become. Already short at 78 minutes, I'm not sure Bakshi had enough ideas to fill up even this small running time. Some of the scenes in the film feel way too drawn out. For a film that is all about radical, revolutionary ideas...It doesn't manage to be anything revolutionary itself.I'm really surprised the film wasn't more controversial when released than it was. Calling parts of it racist wouldn't be a stretch.I would love to see "Fritz the Cat" remade, although an update with today's animation technology would definitely cause the film to lose some of its charm.Overall, "Fritz" is not a masterpiece in any sense of the word nor would I consider it required viewing. If it sounds interesting to you, it's worth seeing just to get the curiosity out of your system. Other than that, it'd be best for you to pass it up.C+

reviewText: Originally released in 1972.I,personally remember seeing this cult classic in a drive-in as well as at a midnight movie(sure miss those anymore;guess since everyone has a DVD player,there's so little call for such).There's STILL something to be said for viewing a movie on a twenty-five foot silver screen.Anyway,'Fritz The Cat' has to be one of the best ever counter-culture flicks ever made.Liked it better than any of the Cheech&Chong movies,except for maybe 'Up In Smoke'.Takes place in New York in the late '60's where good-for-nothing feline Fritz is on a full time search for the sex,drugs and rock&roll lifestyle.The voices in this movie fit right in.Before the likes of Beavis&Butthead,South Park and Family Man,there was this satire.Great animation,I thought.Well worth repeated views.One should enjoy many plays in future years to come.Highly recommended.Ideal humor for aging hippies,former bikers,acid heads and late nighters who don't work at a regular job.
summary: 'Fritz The Cat' (MGM Studios) Running time: 79 minutes

reviewText: Fritz is one funny seeker of Life = Sex. Director Ralph Bakshi has left us an almost forgotten hero of the huge social changes that were simultaneously happening during the Age of Hippiedom.The animation and coloring is just as awesome as when I first saw it at the movies and fans of Robert Crumb will will really dig this. Whether you were there or not, this is a great flick.Rating system was so new when the movie came out it got the "X" rating, heavy "PG" or "R" might be more appropo these days due to drug usage & certain violent scenes against females, so definetly do NOT have young kids around when viewing.Glad to finally own this gem.Fritz the Cat

reviewText: The story concerns a classic 60's hero, Fritz, and his adventures through the urban underground... He loves sex and constantly claims and declares the glories of revolution... At first he is happy with just sex, but as the story moves through exotic adventures he discovers that the only way he can truly be a revolutionary is to join up with one of the militant groups... There, he's over his head...In sharp contrast to Walt Disney's soft characters, Fritz is seen providing a bunch of screaming female cats, placing drugs, and having lots of fun... We are taken through Harlem where, in this case, the blacks are portrayed as jive-talking crows... Fritz is not a fantasy, but an animation venture into super-reality, at least as Bakshi sees it...The animation is unpolished, graceless, but very effective... It has an unrefined or unfinished, renewable energy that brings out some of the social results of the confused sixties...
summary: A shocking but very entertaining film...

reviewText: Written and directed by Ralph Bakshi for his big screen debut, "Fritz the Cat" gives viewers a new look at underground comics legend Robert Crumb's titular character. The most successful independent film of all time (as well as the first animated feature to get an X rating), Fritz' production was marred with controversy surrounding Robert Crumb's approval of subject material, the use of his character and the direction of Bakshi, and led to a host of other X rated animated films (including the sequel "The Nine Lives of Fritz the Cat", which was made without involvement of either Bakshi or Crumb). A must have for the collector of odd and obscure movies.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Now, I understand that movies were very obscure during the '70s (the transition from the psychedlic '60s to the extravagant '80s was a very logical progression), I mean you have exploitation films, movies with a tremendous amount of nudity, and ultra-violence, what more could you want in a decade?  While I was not alive during the time this movie was released I read a review in "Playboy", and I had figured I had better see this movie to decide for myself.  Even by today's standards, this is a very bizarre film, I wish I would have watched this on acid (I would have enjoyed it a lot more, pretty colors anyone).  I almost fell on the floor laughing a few times the first time I saw this.Fritz is a student at NYU, who is bored with life and wants to try something new, unfortunately (to our delight), he bites off a lot more than he can chew.  There's a wild ride through Harlem, cartoon orgies, drug use, and cops portrayed as pigs (literally), what else do you need.  See this movie!
summary: This is a very weird movie!

reviewText: I finally saw FRITZ THE CAT after finding a used copy in Amoeba Records on Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood.I'd have to say it's very dated.  I'm sure, at the time it came out, it was very controversial...but that was before cable TV, internet pornography and the deluge of bad taste, gross humor and obnoxious racism that's flowed out of Hollywood ever since.  Now, it's just...blah.  The filthy streets of NYC would become old hat with both live action (BLADE RUNNER) and animation (HEAVY METAL) 30 years ago.  The racial stereotypes are...racial stereotypes.  Fritz himself is rather bland, and the violence (which I've heard was added for this film) wasn't funny at all.I'm sure that the people who saw it when it first came out will have great memories of it.But those of us who've been bombarded with "racy" humor since then...not so much.
summary: Very Dated...Crumb Probably Still Hates It

reviewText: Fritz The Cat is the story of a NYU dropout who finds the world of peace, love and rock & roll is not all he expected. Anyone who wants to understand how young people at the time saw police (pigs), blacks(crows) and their place in the late 60's & early 70's should watch this cartoon, for there is more truth hidden here than in many serious movies of the same time period. A much better movie by far than the sequel - stay clear of that film!
